perturbation.original_text: 12.4. Dispute Resolution. In the event of any controversy or claim relating to, arising out of or in any way connected to any provision of this Agreement (a "Dispute"), either Party may, by notice to the other Party, have such dispute referred to their respective senior officials designated below or their successors, for attempted resolution by good faith negotiations within 30 days after such notice is received. Any Dispute that is not resolved through such negotiations may be referred to binding arbitration in Denver, Colorado with the Judicial Arbiter Group as part of a 3 person panel, with costs borne separately by each party, to be conducted in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.4. Dispute Resolution. In the event of any controversy or claim relating to, arising out of or in any way connected to any provision of this Agreement (a "Dispute"), either Party may, by notice to the other Party, have such dispute referred to their respective senior officials designated below or their successors, for attempted resolution by good faith negotiations within 30 days after such notice is received. Any Dispute that is not resolved through such negotiations may be referred to non-binding mediation in Denver, Colorado.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies binding arbitration, a legally significant term. Changing this to 'non-binding mediation' significantly alters the dispute resolution process. Arbitration clauses are often scrutinized, and this change undermines the enforceability of the original intent. Dispute resolution should be in its own section, so by changing it there is no direct legal contradiction. However, that can be used to have a basis for an argument.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Arbitration Act, state arbitration laws

perturbation.original_text: 12.3. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the State of New Jersey.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.3. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the State of Delaware.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause specifies that New Jersey law governs the contract. Changing the state to 'Delaware' introduces a conflict, as the contract specifies that Integra is located in New Jersey. This discrepancy makes it unclear which state's laws apply. While the choice of law is generally respected, the contradiction undermines the clarity and enforceability, making it easier to challenge in court. The contract states that the company's HQ is in New Jersey, but by adding Delaware, there is no way to understand which law needs to be considered first.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles of 'meeting of the minds' and clear intent

perturbation.original_text: 5. CONFIDENTIALITY. 5.1. Confidential Information. Except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed to in writing by the parties, each party agrees that, for the term of this Agreement and for 20 years thereafter, it shall keep confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose and shall not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement any Confidential Information furnished to it by the other party pursuant to this Agreement, except that the foregoing shall not apply to any information for which the receiving party can demonstrate that such information: (i) was already known to the receiving party, other than under an obligation of confidentiality, at the time of disclosure by the other party; (ii) was generally available to the public or otherwise part of the public domain at the time of its disclosure to the receiving party; (iii) later became part of the public domain through no act or omission of the receiving party; (iv) was disclosed to the receiving party by a Third Party who had no obligation to the disclosing party not to disclose such information to others; (iv) was independently developed by a person having no knowledge of or access to the disclosing party's Confidential Information; or (v) is an Authorized Disclosure under Section 5.3 below.
perturbation.changed_text: 5. CONFIDENTIALITY. 5.1. Confidential Information. Except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or otherwise agreed to in writing by the parties, each party agrees that, for the term of this Agreement, it shall keep confidential and shall not publish or otherwise disclose and shall not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement any Confidential Information furnished to it by the other party pursuant to this Agreement, except that the foregoing shall not apply to any information for which the receiving party can demonstrate that such information: (i) was already known to the receiving party, other than under an obligation of confidentiality, at the time of disclosure by the other party; (ii) was generally available to the public or otherwise part of the public domain at the time of its disclosure to the receiving party; (iii) later became part of the public domain through no act or omission of the receiving party; (iv) was disclosed to the receiving party by a Third Party who had no obligation to the disclosing party not to disclose such information to others; (iv) was independently developed by a person having no knowledge of or access to the disclosing party's Confidential Information; or (v) is an Authorized Disclosure under Section 5.3 below.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the '20 years thereafter' phrase, the confidentiality clause only extends for the duration of the contract term, rather than providing extended protection. This could significantly impact the protection of trade secrets or other confidential information disclosed during the agreement, especially if those secrets have long-term value. Without the mention of how long after, it can introduce a point of legal contention, especially given the importance of the confidentiality section.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade secret law, contract law principles of reasonable expectations
